awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: how landscape fragmentation interferes with plant-pathogen interactions that maintain local plant diversity
awd_abstract_narration:
Many natural areas are being broken up into smaller fragments due to land-use changes such as suburban sprawl. Compared with larger fragments, small fragments are often extreme environments because they can experience stresses like higher temperatures, more light, and lower soil moisture. This research looks at how plants living in different sized fragments are affected by their pathogens. Interactions between plants and their pathogens are important because although pathogens are best known for the damage they cause they can also help preserve biological diversity. This is because each plant species has its own unique group of pathogens that specialize on it, and slows growth or kills just the plants they infect. This can keep any single plant species from dominating in an area. However, not all pathogens can thrive in the extreme environments found in small patches. It may be that in small patches, different types of pathogens that slow growth or kill multiple plant species indiscriminately are more common. If this is the case, they could decrease plant diversity compared with large patches. By uncovering how plants and pathogens interact in different patch sizes this work will be relevant for understanding the biodiversity consequences of breaking up natural areas, and may affect management of natural landscapes. Both lead researchers for this project are early-career faculty at undergraduate colleges, and will incorporate undergraduate students into all aspects of this work, including community outreach.

Three parallel studies will be conducted to assess how plant-pathogen interactions are altered by landscape fragmentation, focusing on fungal pathogens in particular. First, researchers will bury seeds of twelve plant species in patches of different sizes at the Kansas Fragmentation Site, allowing the seeds to be colonized by potential pathogens and testing to see if the seeds remain viable after a year of burial. This will determine if seed mortality due to fungal pathogens is most influenced by ecological factors that vary with patch size, such as plant host density, plant species richness, and microclimatic conditions (such as temperature and soil moisture). Second, the fungal community from these buried seeds will be characterized using both culture-based methods and culture-independent molecular tools. This will determine whether fungal community structure varies predictably with patch size, host identity, and host density. Finally, a combination of greenhouse and field experiments will test the hypothesis that negative feedbacks (when plants "culture" host-specific pathogens in the soil surrounding their roots) are strongest in the interiors of large patches, rather than on the edges of large patches or in small patches. It is predicted that thermally stressful environments on edges and small patches will favor generalist fungi, reducing the influence of diversity-maintaining feedbacks on smaller fragments. Collectively, these studies link individual plant-fungal interactions to observed landscape patterns in plant diversity.

por.por_cntn:
In this study, we explored how landscape fragmentation may disrupt interactions between plants and their fungal pathogens. Fungal pathogens can play an important role in regulating plant population size. In some cases, pathogens can help to maintain plant diversity. Plant species accumulate a specific fungal pathogen community in soil near their roots, and these fungi may keep that plant species in check by attacking individual plants of the same species more frequently than plants of other species. However, the changes caused by landscape fragmentation - including changes to the plant community as well as environmental conditions like temperature and soil moisture - may disrupt the interactions between plants and their pathogens that are key to plant population regulation and diversity maintenance. We focused our work on the seed stage, since plant seeds are particularly vulnerable to soil pathogens and can persist in the soil for weeks to years, allowing for fungal infection. 

We buried seeds of fourteen different plant species (>100,000 seeds total for the full experiment) across an experimentally fragmented landscape in Lawrence, KS. This field site was originally plowed and farmed, and was allowed to regrow as patches of young forested habitat of different sizes, with mowed grassland in between. Seeds were buried on the edges of large (50 m x 100 m) patches, in the interiors of large patches, within small (4 x 8 m) patches, or in the grassy area between forest patches. We installed a network of sensors that measured soil moisture and temperature at high frequency. After a year of burial, seeds were exhumed. This collaborative project had several components, but work at Sarah Lawrence College focused on identifying which fungi were inhabiting these buried seeds. We identified fungi using two different methods: culturing live fungi from freshly unearthed seeds, and amplifying fungal DNA from seeds using high-throughput DNA sequencing. 

We identified over 1,300 cultures of live fungi from six plant species using DNA barcoding, and found over 250 different fungal types. We tested the hypotheses that identities of these seed-associated fungi were dependent on seed host identity, landscape location (large interior, large edge, small, matrix), soil temperature, and soil moisture. We found that the identity of the fungal community associated with seeds depended on not only the plant species, but also the soil environment where seeds were buried. A subset of the fungi grown in cultures have been used in pathogenicity assays to demonstrate that they can indeed harm their seed hosts, and that these effects are differential by host species. By using high-throughput DNA sequencing methods, we found an even richer fungal community from eleven plant species, over 10,000 types of fungi. We continue to work with this extensive dataset to look at the determinants of fungal community composition, including the surrounding plant community and other environmental factors associated with habitat fragmentation.

Along with the scientific goals of this research, this project has accomplished several educational and outreach goals. Undergraduate students have been instrumental to this work and have in fact collected the majority of the data. This grant has been the impetus for the development of a new course at Sarah Lawrence College, Environmental Metagenomics, which gave students access to high-throughput sequencing methods that had not been previously used at the college. This research has been incorporated into other courses as well (Microbiology, Disease Ecology) and has spawned multiple independent research projects by undergraduates. We have also developed several cross-institutional collaborations between courses at Bard College and Sarah Lawrence College. Finally, we have worked with students in Yonkers, NY via lab experiences for high school students and workshops for local students working in a community garden.
